question: Are remaining failures in realistic operating ranges or only in stress-test extremes?

parameter_ranges.rationale: Typical accepted standardized residual/effect magnitudes in DSL simulation workflows are in low-to-moderate bands; >6 is usually outlier or run-quality failure.
Computational Bayesian model comparisons often lie in low hundreds; high hundreds/low thousands can occur under strong cumulative evidence.
For nonnegative contradiction-oriented custom metrics, x0<0 implies half-activation before zero evidence and over-amplifies weak signals.
Moderate slopes preserve weak-signal gradation; very steep k behaves like hard thresholding and is usually stress calibration.
2-3x inflation can occur with sampling variability; 5-10x usually indicates non-equilibrated or low-quality runs.
Partial uncertainty omissions occur, but most metrics missing uncertainty is typically a QA/reporting failure.
Valid physical regime shifts usually involve coupled metrics; isolated extreme one-metric jumps are usually artifacts.

pattern_b_domain_assessment.rationale: Large transitions exist but typically co-move multiple observables; isolated 50x one-metric spikes are non-nominal.
Abrupt climate changes are coupled and temporally distributed; one-metric 50x step is non-standard for valid outputs.
Extreme spikes can occur in non-converged SCF behavior, but those runs are rejected rather than used as valid evidence.

failure_overlay.rationale: Failure locus requires negative x0; all sampled x0>=0 points pass in Session 4 grid.
Pattern B is an intentionally extreme stress shape not representative of nominal valid DSL outputs.
Observed failure occurs beyond realistic uncertainty inflation for quality-controlled runs.
Session 4.1 log-scaled normalization (bf_max_target=10000) restores S5 through BF=1000.

failure_overlay.boundary_value: old mapping failed in high d_mid/high BF cells
failure_overlay.rationale: Same Session 4.1 BF normalization recovered all five previously failing S6 cells.
